AN ACT to alter the time of holding the Dis


trict Court of the United States for the South


ern District of Alabama, and for other purpos-


es.


Be ii enacted By the Senate and House Of
Representatives Of the United States of .d-
merica in Congress assembled, That the
Diatriet Court of the United States, for the
Southern District Of Alabama, shall be holden in
the city of Mobile, ON the second Monday in De-
cember instead Of the second Monday in October,
and IN addition to the term now directed by law
10 be holden on the first Monday in May in each
and every year, and shall continue so long as bu-
slness may require.


SEC. 9. ind be il further enacted, That
the records and papers belonging to the Dis
trict Court heretofore holden at the town of
Cahawba, in the Southern District of Alabama,
except such as may be necessary in any crmn-
al prosecution pending in the said Court, shall
be transferred to, and become part of the re-
cords and papers of the District Court holden at
Mobile, and all causes of a civil nature pending
in the District Court heretofore holden at the
said town of Cahawba, shall be transferred to the
District Court holden in the city of Mobile, and
shall have day therein and be proceeded in to
final Judgment and execution, in the same man
ner rs fthe said cause had originated in the said
Court holden at Mobile; and it shall be lawful
for the SAID last mentioned court to issue eXecu-
,ion upon any Judgment heretofore rendered in
the District Court holden at Cahawba, which
said Judgment shall not have been satisfied, and
to issue writs of scire 'facas for the purpose Of
reviving any Judgment heretofore rendered by
the District Court holden at Cahawba, and to is
sue all other wrts or process which may be ne
cessary, according to the course of judicial pro-
ceedngs.


SEC. 8. ind be il further enacted, That
Ill causes of criminal nature, now pending in
the District Court holden at Cahawba, shall be
proceeded in by said Court, to final judgment,
ard to execution of such judgment or sentence
as may be rendered by the said Court, in the
| said causes; and, that Immediately thereafter, the
records and papers in the said causes shall be
transferred to, and become a part of, the records
and papers Of the District Court, holden at Mo.
bile.


approved March 2, 1897.

AN ACT giving further compensation TO the


Captains and Subalterns of the Army of the


United States, in certain cases.


Be il enacted By the Senate and House Of
Representatives ofhe United States IF f.
n,erica in Congress assembled, That from
and after the passing of this act, each captain
and snbaltein iii the Army shall be allowed one
additional ration


SEC. 2. Ind be 1t further enacted, That ev.
cry officer in the actual command of company
in the Army Of the United States, shall be enti-
tied to receive ten dollars per month additional
pay, as compensation for his duties and respon-
abilities, with respect to the clothing, arms and
accoutrements of the company, whilst he shall
be in the actual command thereof Provided.
That no Subaltern officer who shall be in the
p r;ormance ofany staff duty, for which he re-
ceves an extra compensation, shall be entitled
to the additional ration herein provided for.


Approved: Mach 2, 1897.

Captain Woimwood Of Surry, Me took his
wife and child into sleigh and attempted TO
cross Patterns BAY upon the ice, but before reach
inlethe other side the ice broke and they were all
plunged into tic congcalin& element, with the
sleigh turned directly over them. Iic cane up
IN one direction, and the wife and child in anoth-
cr. Mrs Wornwooh disappeared seyyeral times,
but every time She arose it was with extended
arms cndcayo.ns to throw her infant out Of dan.
cey; and by her psiscyering ehoits, ard the mid
Of i wise Providence, she kept heTsoltand 'he
littlc sufferer above the water, until Captain
Wormwood swan to her relief, threw the babe
on the ice, and finally succeeded in saving the
lives OF all three; but the horse was lost. We
understand that the personal Indifference, pater-
nal solicitudc, and extraordinary efforts Of this
woman while in the perious situation above dc
scribcd, we're of the most interesting character

Great excr,ions are making by the Clergy, the
Press the Theatres and Ball parties, and by pii-
vatc individuals, in many parts of this country,
to relieve tire Cracks from their suiferngs, incl
dent to a nation struggling for political liberty.
We know not whether the bondage Of the
Greeks in Turkey, has been Of a more cruel and
degrading character than that Of the American
slaves But il it has been half as much SO, their
situation might well excite the sympathy OF eve
ry philanthrophic mind


hut in the meantime, it is hoped, that this hea.
W Grecian draft may not exhaust the fund OF
American humanity, till the deeply suffered and
tyrannicaly degraded slave population of this
country of unequal rights, is relieved. The
Greeks have suffered a political bondage. The
slaves of this land of political freedom, suffer II
political, physical, transferable and inerminable
bondage. JUSTICE.

faun, the prisoner being upon the horse, rode

full articles.headline: TPublic-No. 24.1
full articles.article:
AN ACT to alter the time of holding the Dis


trict Court of the United States for the South


ern District of Alabama, and for other purpos-


es.


Be ii enacted By the Senate and House Of
Representatives Of the United States of .d-
merica in Congress assembled, That the
Diatriet Court of the United States, for the
Southern District Of Alabama, shall be holden in
the city of Mobile, ON the second Monday in De-
cember instead Of the second Monday in October,
and IN addition to the term now directed by law
10 be holden on the first Monday in May in each
and every year, and shall continue so long as bu-
slness may require.


SEC. 9. ind be il further enacted, That
the records and papers belonging to the Dis
trict Court heretofore holden at the town of
Cahawba, in the Southern District of Alabama,
except such as may be necessary in any crmn-
al prosecution pending in the said Court, shall
be transferred to, and become part of the re-
cords and papers of the District Court holden at
Mobile, and all causes of a civil nature pending
in the District Court heretofore holden at the
said town of Cahawba, shall be transferred to the
District Court holden in the city of Mobile, and
shall have day therein and be proceeded in to
final Judgment and execution, in the same man
ner rs fthe said cause had originated in the said
Court holden at Mobile; and it shall be lawful
for the SAID last mentioned court to issue eXecu-
,ion upon any Judgment heretofore rendered in
the District Court holden at Cahawba, which
said Judgment shall not have been satisfied, and
to issue writs of scire 'facas for the purpose Of
reviving any Judgment heretofore rendered by
the District Court holden at Cahawba, and to is
sue all other wrts or process which may be ne
cessary, according to the course of judicial pro-
ceedngs.


SEC. 8. ind be il further enacted, That
Ill causes of criminal nature, now pending in
the District Court holden at Cahawba, shall be
proceeded in by said Court, to final judgment,
ard to execution of such judgment or sentence
as may be rendered by the said Court, in the
| said causes; and, that Immediately thereafter, the
records and papers in the said causes shall be
transferred to, and become a part of, the records
and papers Of the District Court, holden at Mo.
bile.

full articles.headline: fPUBLIc. No. 95.1
full articles.article:
AN ACT giving further compensation TO the


Captains and Subalterns of the Army of the


United States, in certain cases.


Be il enacted By the Senate and House Of
Representatives ofhe United States IF f.
n,erica in Congress assembled, That from
and after the passing of this act, each captain
and snbaltein iii the Army shall be allowed one
additional ration


SEC. 2. Ind be 1t further enacted, That ev.
cry officer in the actual command of company
in the Army Of the United States, shall be enti-
tied to receive ten dollars per month additional
pay, as compensation for his duties and respon-
abilities, with respect to the clothing, arms and
accoutrements of the company, whilst he shall
be in the actual command thereof Provided.
That no Subaltern officer who shall be in the
p r;ormance ofany staff duty, for which he re-
ceves an extra compensation, shall be entitled
to the additional ration herein provided for.


Approved: Mach 2, 1897.

full articles.headline: EXTRAORDINARY ESCAPE.
full articles.article:
Captain Woimwood Of Surry, Me took his
wife and child into sleigh and attempted TO
cross Patterns BAY upon the ice, but before reach
inlethe other side the ice broke and they were all
plunged into tic congcalin& element, with the
sleigh turned directly over them. Iic cane up
IN one direction, and the wife and child in anoth-
cr. Mrs Wornwooh disappeared seyyeral times,
but every time She arose it was with extended
arms cndcayo.ns to throw her infant out Of dan.
cey; and by her psiscyering ehoits, ard the mid
Of i wise Providence, she kept heTsoltand 'he
littlc sufferer above the water, until Captain
Wormwood swan to her relief, threw the babe
on the ice, and finally succeeded in saving the
lives OF all three; but the horse was lost. We
understand that the personal Indifference, pater-
nal solicitudc, and extraordinary efforts Of this
woman while in the perious situation above dc
scribcd, we're of the most interesting character

full articles.headline: 1lIE CREEKS.
full articles.article:
Great excr,ions are making by the Clergy, the
Press the Theatres and Ball parties, and by pii-
vatc individuals, in many parts of this country,
to relieve tire Cracks from their suiferngs, incl
dent to a nation struggling for political liberty.
We know not whether the bondage Of the
Greeks in Turkey, has been Of a more cruel and
degrading character than that Of the American
slaves But il it has been half as much SO, their
situation might well excite the sympathy OF eve
ry philanthrophic mind


hut in the meantime, it is hoped, that this hea.
W Grecian draft may not exhaust the fund OF
American humanity, till the deeply suffered and
tyrannicaly degraded slave population of this
country of unequal rights, is relieved. The
Greeks have suffered a political bondage. The
slaves of this land of political freedom, suffer II
political, physical, transferable and inerminable
bondage. JUSTICE.

followed TO Albany, and from thence to n York,
where thcy chartered pilot boat 10 the Hook,
,about 80 niles for which they paid $50 dollars,
where ,hey were pitt on board the brig Brown,
which sailed Immediately.

full articles.headline:
For tic Hilmingionian.
ODE TO sERxN &.
full articles.article:
HAIL! gentle spring, thy infant nowrcts now
Qncc more arc opening in perennial births
1hy lovely offspring TO the zephyrs bow,


Which long had slumbcr'd i'll cold sterile


earth.


Yes beautcous spriag! love thy sylvan reign,
Thou hast no tcrrurs like the mondrch flown;
At thy approach all nature blooms again,


And smiling beatty claims thee Us her own
l'hy little herslds with mclodioia song,


Proclaimed the truth of tyrant Wmir gone
And Joy would bil still swcctcr notes prolong
Tie pleasing tidings thou vert Fastening on.
Yes-sec the lowly violcts spread


Thertcndcr foliage, aud their cups Of blue;
While from their breasts pleasing fragrance


shed,


And fearless drink the balmy evening dew
And yon lone tree, all dcsulatc and barre


mark d It's blight, and thought its time was
But 10, it buds!-t will thy bounty share,


IL has thy blessing, and will bloom once more
Sweet season--tho short Thy visit here,


Yet thou viii many Aorrowlng heart hegulle;
rhy peaceful calm can sooth affections tear,


And porerty itself viii often smile.
VIVA, haples, mrrads OF the wretchcd poor,


Will hail ,hy coming with internal Glee;
No longer forced 10 beg from door to door,


Their ssreAgt&, ,hcirh pes arc both renew'd in


thee.


And thou, sweet stream, tiat pensive glides a.


long


Thy rugged bed, mcandc,ins finds lis ways
Thou w',o hast gaccd full many potFS song,


Shall brightly bloom in sweet luxurianl dltY.
Thy lofty hills crown'd with majestic oak,
Ihy vcrlant lawns, and fragrant laeads below,
Thy tow'rinc rocks, which time has never broke,
Around whose base the moss-shrub towiet4
grow


AN, all, dear Rrandywine, shall send
A blooming tribute to thy stream TO iavri
And in thy bosom, with sweet union blend,


Reflect their bcau .es from thy lucid wave.
Yes, lovely stream, soon will thy margins be
\ The fond recipients of those gifts coubin'd;
But I, alas! thy brightness may not see,


But in the vision Of sorrowlng mind
All, no--for soon ! so to live
In other paris--in ether climes to be;
Dear scenes Of youth, yet will ever give


My hearts bcs, feelings, and my thoughta t'


thee


Mary, wilt thou perinit me here


To draw a n,oyoi from this humble lay
And should it urge coir'c'ton' silent tear,


Oh. wipe not then that silent tear away
Thou art dear girl, now in the bloom OF youth


Thy Spring is opening with luxus.ant charms
As vet, thou art the fayour'd child OF ifWh,


And thy young heart'sa stranger to alarms
f Yet deem not thus thy hiict days viii end
| The world is cold, is streachcrous, nStncerei
o, never never on It's fdh depend,
. twill pierce thy SOUL and call aiiict'on's tear
Then trust it not--.for there are Ills in life
Umthought OF now that thou wilt have 10 mee'
For Rates uncrring and destructive knie


Oft snaps our pleasures when they are mo-


sweet.
J All then. be wisc,--an. now in life's younS da!
Ere E0Ny's banc its poison shall imparti
O snatch the weeds OF ranking vice away
, And plant the seeds OF p'tue IN tliy heafe'
There let them bloom--and when thy b"mnaeF
DER,
7 If weeds of gttiH shall not have m'sTled M
4 Thy .P4tunn then Will but enripen more
e The sacred fruit Of Piety within
/ and when from earth thy spirit shall remove,
Borne on the swiftncss of an angels wing,
Transplanted hence, in yon pure soil above,
1 Thou'lt blossom, A.ary, i'll Eternal Spring!
BRANDywlNE MINSTREL.

} For tie lPIimingtoa,aa.

SIC. 5. .q,d be ii further enacfea, That the

A nan was committed oi grand larceny q Al
bany during the last month. The offence wa
committed three years beiore, in the manner fol-
lowing: The prisoner being arrested for debt
ne borrowed So dollars 70 cents OF a person, and
to secure its repayment, executed bill OF sale
on horse worth 200 dollars, by way of mort
gage. He then agreed 10 work on that persons
farm for ten dollars month, and have the horse
Ia charge as his hired man On their way TO the
faun, the prisoner being upon the horse, rode
OF and afterwards sol him.

FIRE.--The Grist Mill Of Messrs. q. {. S. Rob
inson, at Oxford Furnace, N. ]. was burnt down
on the 25th March,. a large quantity Of grain, and
a set of carding machines were destroyed; loss
$4,000.


The Quebec Gazette states that more snow fell
in the month Of March, than had fallen since the
opening of winter.


Mr.. Secretary Barbour left Washington City
on Thursday week, on visit TO his seat in Vir-
gina,


Samuel l.. Knapp, recently of Boston, is
SAID to be engaged as editor Of the National
Journal, at Washington City, in place of Mr..
Age, who has conducted the paper since
the last election of President.
The vote was taken in the Pennsylvania
house of Representatives, on "Wednesday, on
the address for the re'nova, Of Judge Franks,
and was in favor of the address 46, against
il s.; there not being two thirds OF the house
il favor, the address was not carried.
